title: Can humans ever understand themselves? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. And no. It depends on what is meant by “understand”. We know a lot of stuff by observation and recognizing patterns, forming ideas and testing those ideas, etc. This is true for both “objective” knowledge, such as our observations of others and scientific research, as well as “subjective” knowledge, such as the things one learns by disciplined self-observation. But there are limits to the kind of knowledge which comes from observation, analysis, synthesis, and theory. The understanding that we get that way is very useful, and we pursue it for good reasons. But it’s still limited. An idea is a mere static representation of some fragment of reality: we have to draw mental boundaries around some aspect of our experience and give it a name, categorize it, etc., then we use that elemental idea to construct larger models of how things work, and we call the result “knowledge” or “understanding.” We feel that we understand when it all makes sense to us — i.e. when causality is accounted for and we can predict outcomes based on our understanding. Even so, as good as our model might be, it will always suffer a defect that’s attributed to its origins. When you take reality and “carve it up” cognitively, you’re doing a kind of damage — truth is lost in the process. The wholeness of reality cannot be represented. It can’t be packaged and labeled and used as a part in a model. This loss of truth is inescapable. There is absolutely nothing one can do about the shortcomings of conceptuality as a means to knowledge — nobody will ever overcome that limitation, because it’s built-in to what a concept is: “a unit of representation of some aspect of reality.” All is not lost, though. There’s a kind of “knowing” which doesn’t involve that carve-up-and-label process. This kind of knowing is so different than what we normally think of as knowledge that it’s probably best not to call it knowledge, but something else. The “something else” that I like for this is being. Being is a kind of knowledge which doesn’t depend on carved-up symbolic representations of some aspect of reality. Being is whole, like reality is whole. To be is to “know” yourself, not as a bunch of ideas, but as an unbounded presence beyond language and ideas. You can’t really say what it is, because talking is all about those carved-up symbols, and you can’t really even think about it clearly. But you can still be it anyway.
